blocks.text: The BG2FX FX-4CR is a compact SDR transceiver covering HF bands plus 50 MHz (6m). It provides 20W output on SSB and CW, with multiple operating modes including USB, LSB, CW, AM, and FM.
Power on by pressing the power button. The color LCD displays frequency, mode, S-meter, and various operating parameters. The main encoder controls frequency tuning.
Band selection is via the BAND button, cycling through available amateur bands from 160m through 6m. Each band stores the last used frequency and mode.
Mode selection (USB/LSB/CW/AM/FM) is performed with the MODE button. The radio automatically selects appropriate sideband for phone operation based on band.
The FX-4CR supports split operation with separate VFO A and B frequencies. Use the A/B button to toggle VFOs and SPLIT to enable split mode.
As an SDR radio, the FX-4CR offers flexible filtering and a spectrum display for visualizing band activity.
Access the menu system by pressing MENU. Navigate with the main encoder and select items by pressing the encoder. Press MENU again to exit.

blocks.name: CW Speed
blocks.description: Sets internal keyer speed from 5-50 WPM

blocks.name: CW Pitch
blocks.description: Sets CW receive tone offset (400-800 Hz)

blocks.name: Keyer Mode
blocks.description: Straight key, Iambic A, Iambic B, or Bug mode

blocks.name: Mic Gain
blocks.description: Sets microphone input level for SSB/AM/FM

blocks.name: AGC Mode
blocks.description: Selects Fast, Medium, or Slow AGC response

blocks.name: Spectrum Settings
blocks.description: Spectrum display span and reference level

blocks.text: The FX-4CR includes a full-featured electronic keyer with speeds from 5-50 WPM. Iambic A, Iambic B, and Bug emulation modes are supported.
Connect a paddle to the keyer jack (3.5mm). Standard wiring is tip=dit, ring=dah, sleeve=ground. Paddle swap is available in the menu.
CW pitch (sidetone frequency) is adjustable and also sets the receive offset. This ensures the sidetone matches the received signal when zero-beat.
The radio provides CW semi break-in (QSK) operation with adjustable delay. Full QSK may be available depending on firmware version.
CW filter bandwidth is adjustable via the DSP from 50 Hz to 2.4 kHz, allowing narrow filtering for contest or wide for comfortable ragchewing.
The SDR architecture provides excellent CW filter shapes with steep skirts for effective adjacent signal rejection.
As an SDR transceiver, the FX-4CR offers flexible DSP filtering. Filter bandwidth is continuously adjustable with preset widths for each mode.
SSB bandwidth is adjustable from 1.8 kHz to 3.0 kHz. CW bandwidth ranges from 50 Hz to 2.4 kHz. AM and FM have appropriate fixed bandwidths.
Noise Reduction (NR) uses DSP algorithms to reduce background noise on SSB and CW signals. Four intensity levels are available.
Noise Blanker (NB) suppresses impulse noise from sources like ignition or switching power supplies. Adjustable threshold prevents false triggering.
Notch filter (auto or manual) removes heterodynes and carriers from the passband. Auto-notch tracks and eliminates multiple interfering tones.
AGC (Automatic Gain Control) offers Fast, Medium, and Slow settings. Fast AGC is useful for contests, while Slow provides smoother audio for casual operation.
The FX-4CR operates from 10.5-16V DC input. A standard DC power connector is provided. Nominal operation is at 13.8V.
Current consumption is approximately 500mA on receive (with display backlight) and up to 4A during transmit at full 20W output.
For portable operation, a 4S LiPo or 4S LiFePO4 battery provides adequate voltage. Current consumption makes extended portable operation feasible with appropriately sized batteries.
Do not exceed 16V input voltage. Use appropriate fusing for the power cable. Do not reverse polarity.
At reduced power settings (5-10W), battery life is significantly extended while maintaining effective communication range for most conditions.
The FX-4CR does not include an internal automatic antenna tuner. An external ATU is recommended for multi-band operation with non-resonant antennas.
The radio includes SWR metering displayed on screen. Monitor SWR and use an external tuner to achieve below 2:1 before transmitting at full power.
For portable operation, compact ATUs like the Elecraft T1 or mAT-10 pair well with the FX-4CR's power level.
The radio includes protective circuits that reduce power output when SWR is excessively high.

blocks.text: No power: Check DC voltage (10.5-16V required). Verify polarity and fuse. Some units have internal fuses - check if accessible.
No or low RF output: Check antenna and SWR. Verify mode selection. Check TX power setting. Ensure PTT or VOX is properly activating TX.
Audio distortion on SSB: Reduce mic gain. Check compression settings. Ensure correct microphone type is configured.
CW keying problems: Check paddle wiring and keyer mode setting. Verify CW speed is appropriate. Try straight key mode to isolate issue.
Spectrum display issues: Adjust reference level in spectrum settings. Try different span settings. Check if NB/NR is causing display artifacts.
Receiver overload: Enable attenuator on strong signal bands. Check AGC settings. Consider adding external filtering for contest environments.
